Book Title: Statistical Decision Theory and Bayesian Analysis
Author:
J. O. Berger
A rigorous, graduate-level treatment linking decision theory and Bayesian inference. Covers loss functions, admissibility, minimaxity, complete classes, hierarchical/empirical Bayes, and foundations of Bayesian decision-making.
Key strengths & uses:
• Deep theoretical foundations connecting decisions and inference.
• Comprehensive on admissibility and decision‑theoretic results.
• Excellent as a reference for advanced Bayesian theory.
Recommended level: Advanced (graduate/research)
Summary:
Statistical Inference — George Casella & Roger L. Berger
A modern, mathematically rigorous introduction to statistical inference. Topics include probability review, estimation, testing, likelihood methods, decision theory, asymptotics, and Bayesian methods.
Key strengths & uses:
• Well organized and thorough for theory courses.
• Balanced coverage of frequentist and Bayesian ideas.
• Good exercises and theoretical proofs.
Recommended level: Advanced (graduate/upper‑undergraduate)

Book Title: All of Statistics: A Concise Course in Statistical Inference
Author:
Larry Wasserman
A compact, broad textbook covering probability, estimation, testing, nonparametrics, bootstrapping, density estimation, and classification — designed to quickly equip readers with essential statistical tools.
Key strengths & uses:
• Great breadth in a single volume.
• Accessible to mathematically mature readers.
• Popular with data scientists and CS students.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced (self‑study)
Summary:
Introduction to the Theory of Statistics — Mood, Graybill & Boes
A classical text presenting probability and statistical inference with clear derivations. Emphasizes theoretical development of estimation, hypothesis testing, and sampling distributions.
Key strengths & uses:
• Classic presentation of sampling distributions and classical inference.
• Detailed worked examples.
• Good historical and foundational perspective.
Recommended level: Intermediate (undergraduate/early graduate)

Author:
Wackerly, Mendenhall & Scheaffer
A widely used textbook combining theory and applied examples. Covers probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, ANOVA, and practical data analysis with exercises and applications.
Key strengths & uses:
• Balances theory and application for students.
• Numerous examples and exercises.
• Friendly exposition for applied courses.
Recommended level: Undergraduate to Intermediate
Summary:
Theoretical Statistics — D. R. Cox & D. V. Hinkley
A compact, elegantly written book focusing on likelihood-based inference and asymptotic theory. Emphasizes conceptual clarity and the role of the likelihood in statistical practice.
Key strengths & uses:
• Clear treatment of likelihood methods and asymptotics.
• Philosophical and practical insights from leading statisticians.
• Concise but deep — great for building intuition.
Recommended level: Advanced (graduate/research)

Author:
Erich L. Lehmann & George Casella
An authoritative reference on point estimation covering unbiasedness, sufficiency, completeness, estimation bounds, Bayes and minimax estimators, and asymptotic methods.
Key strengths & uses:
• Comprehensive theory of estimation.
• Rigorous proofs and advanced results.
• Essential reference for theoretical statisticians.
Recommended level: Advanced (graduate/research)
Summary:
Testing Statistical Hypotheses — Erich L. Lehmann & Joseph P. Romano
A definitive treatment of hypothesis testing theory: Neyman–Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio tests, UMP tests, multiple testing, and asymptotic approaches.
Key strengths & uses:
• Foundational coverage of testing theory.
• Formal treatment of optimality and power.
• Valuable for both theory and applied methodology.
Recommended level: Advanced (graduate/research)

Book Title: The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference, and Prediction
Author:
Hastie, Tibshirani & Friedman
A comprehensive book on modern predictive modeling and machine learning: linear methods, trees, boosting, SVMs, kernels, ensemble methods, and unsupervised learning, with an applied and algorithmic focus.
Key strengths & uses:
• Excellent breadth on machine learning algorithms.
• Combines intuition with mathematical detail.
• Extensive examples and applications in R.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced (applied/ML focus)
Summary:
Probability and Statistics — DeGroot & Schervish
A unified book that introduces probability theory and statistical inference with clarity; covers Bayesian methods, decision theory, estimation, testing, and stochastic processes.
Key strengths & uses:
• Well‑balanced treatment of probability and inference.
• Good for courses bridging probability and applied statistics.
• Clear examples and exercises.
Recommended level: Undergraduate to Intermediate

Book Title: An Introduction to Probability Theory and Its Applications
Author:
William Feller (Vol. I & II)
A two‑volume classic offering deep, rigorous, and often playful exposition of probability theory with many examples, limit theorems, combinatorial probability, and stochastic processes.
Key strengths & uses:
• Masterful and rigorous treatment of probability.
• Rich set of problems and classical examples.
• Historically influential and elegant.
Recommended level: Advanced (mathematical/probability focus)
Summary:
Introduction to Mathematical Statistics — Hogg, McKean & Craig
A solid textbook presenting probability and statistical inference with emphasis on computation, distributions, estimation, and hypothesis testing, often used in undergraduate/first-year graduate courses.
Key strengths & uses:
• Clear exposition and practical examples.
• Good balance of theory and applied exercises.
• Widely adopted for core statistics courses.
Recommended level: Undergraduate to Intermediate

Author:
Gelman, Carlin, Stern, Dunson, Vehtari & Rubin
A comprehensive, pragmatic guide to Bayesian methods: modeling, hierarchical models, MCMC computation, model checking, and applied examples across sciences.
Key strengths & uses:
• Practical focus on modeling and computation.
• Extensive real‑world examples and case studies.
• Covers modern Bayesian workflow and diagnostics.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced (applied Bayesian)
Summary:
Survey Sampling — Leslie Kish
A classical, practical text on survey sampling design and estimation: simple, stratified, cluster, and multistage sampling; weighting; variance estimation; and design effects.
Key strengths & uses:
• Authoritative on survey design and practical sampling issues.
• Focus on design-based inference and real surveys.
• Classic reference for survey practitioners.
Recommended level: Intermediate (survey methodology)

Author:
William G. Cochran
A foundational text on sampling methodology covering design, estimation, stratification, cluster sampling, and practical implementation of sampling plans.
Key strengths & uses:
• Clear theoretical and practical coverage of sampling.
• Widely used in survey and sampling courses.
• Good worked examples and formulas for practitioners.
Recommended level: Intermediate (survey/sample design)
Summary:
Design and Analysis of Experiments — Douglas C. Montgomery
A practical and accessible guide to experimental design: factorial designs, ANOVA, blocking, randomization, response surface methods, and industrial applications.
Key strengths & uses:
• Very applied with engineering/industrial examples.
• Step‑by‑step guidance for designing experiments.
• Useful for both students and practicing engineers/statisticians.
Recommended level: Undergraduate to Intermediate (applied)

Author:
Johnson & Wichern
A comprehensive exposition of multivariate methods: multivariate normal theory, MANOVA, principal components, factor analysis, clustering, discriminant analysis, and canonical correlation.
Key strengths & uses:
• Thorough coverage of multivariate techniques.
• Mathematical detail plus applied examples.
• Standard graduate course text in multivariate analysis.
Recommended level: Advanced (multivariate methods)
Summary:
Time Series Analysis: Forecasting and Control — Box, Jenkins, Reinsel & Ljung
The canonical applied text on time series modeling and forecasting: ARIMA, model identification, estimation, diagnostic checking, and forecasting practice; includes Box–Jenkins methodology.
Key strengths & uses:
• Practical, hands‑on approach to time series.
• Strong emphasis on model building and diagnostics.
• Widely used by forecasters in industry and academia.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced (time series)

Author:
Alan Agresti
A thorough treatment of methods for analyzing categorical data: contingency tables, logistic regression, log‑linear models, multinomial responses, and model diagnostics.
Key strengths & uses:
• Comprehensive coverage of categorical models and inference.
• Accessible explanations with practical examples.
• Valuable for applied researchers working with discrete outcomes.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced
Summary:
Nonparametric Statistical Methods — Hollander & Wolfe
A classic text on nonparametric inference: rank tests, permutation methods, goodness‑of‑fit tests, and nonparametric regression and estimation techniques.
Key strengths & uses:
• Careful exposition of rank and permutation methods.
• Good balance between theory and application.
• Useful when model assumptions are suspect.
Recommended level: Intermediate to Advanced (nonparametric methods)
